NikeNike It was a window into the future. On December 7, more than 400 of the countryâ€™s best distance runners traveled to Portland, Ore., for the Nike Cross Nationals (NXN) Finals. You especially see that during NXN, with how the pros travel here on race day to encourage the high school runners. For these high school kids, a big part of their experience is shaped by seeing these accomplished runners who they admire, and whoâ€™ve competed in this race themselves, cheering them on. NikeNike As a young girl attending a Native American boarding school on the Cherokee Nation Reservation in Oklahoma, Dr.Christine Panther remembers being taught the cultural practice of rising before dawn to greet the sun. That daily reverence toward the natural world helped inspire Panther, whose origins trace back to Oklahomaâ€™s Kiowa, Quapaw and Shawnee Nations, to take up running throughout high school and into her adulthood. Many Indigenous communities across the world share the same sentiment: Nature can be a conduit to movement, which, in turn, is a conduit for change. â€œIndigenous communities across the world honor nature through movement and sport,â€ says Panther, a Sr. Manager, Social & Community Impact (SCI) at Nike. â€œSport is medicine. Sport opens up a world of possibilities outside our door, especially for our young people. Thatâ€™s why the N7 Fundâ€™s connection to movement and sport is so vital, and so transformative.â€ Among Pantherâ€™s responsibilities within SCI is to help facilitate the N7 Fund application process, which is now open through January 6. The program recognizes nonprofitsÂ at all scales, from grassroots to the national level, thatÂ are increasing access to sport for Indigenous youth across North America. Watching these groups use the power of sport to change lives for the better is a privilege, says Panther. Her work at Nike, she says, places her within a proud lineage ofÂ Indigenous leaders andÂ organizations, past and present, who see movement as a pathway toward transformation.  â€œThe N7 Fund follows the proverbial wisdom of Indigenous communities to consider the impact of our choices on the seventh generation,â€ says Panther. â€œThe children from this and future generations are benefitting from the tireless work of our partners, which the fund helps support. Getting a front-row seat to see how they will change the world is an honor.â€ Learn more about the N7 Fund and apply at https://lnkd.in/g-BSm_4Bhashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#NikeN7Fund hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Did you see that breakaway?! NikeNike When Christopher Hicks was in the first grade, he had zero interest in playing baseball.But one persistent voice â€” Coach Walter at the local Boys & Girls Club â€” convinced him to step onto the diamond anyway, igniting a lifelong love for sport.Now, many years later, heâ€™s giving back in the same way his coach did. Those experiences set him up for an incredible full-circle moment nearly 10 years later during his first Nike project: expanding the Mamba League throughout Los Angeles. And on his initial site visit to the Boys & Girls Club of Wilmington, guess who opened the door? Coach Walter, still supporting local youth as the clubâ€™s transportation director.â€œI recognized him immediately,â€ Hicks says. â€œSeeing his continued commitment to the community after all these years was inspiring.â€Like Coach Walterâ€™s dedication, the Mamba League is rooted in Kobeâ€™s vision: empowering young athletes through inclusive coaching, equal playing time, age-appropriate equipment and at least 50% girls participation.â€œThatâ€™s what itâ€™s all about for me,â€ Hicks says. â€œThrough Mamba League, we get to spark joy for kids across L.A. and keep them in the game.â€Read more about how Nike is powering the future of youth sport: https://lnkd.in/gSXe6AsChashtag#MambaLeague hashtag#NikeImpact hashtag#FutureOfSport hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike As Nikeâ€™s longest-tenured employee on the Social & Community Impact team â€” 47 years with the Swoosh and counting!Â â€” Kathy Webb,Â Nike Employee Community Engagement Director, knows a thing or two about legacy.
